Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer to Advance Undergraduate Education and Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Debra Dolliver from Southeastern Louisiana University and colleague Jean Fotie will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) development of synthetic techniques to make single geometric isomers of imine derivatives; (b) design and synthesis of biologically active molecules as potential antiprotozoan agents; (c) support of the program SEAL (Student Entrepreneurs as Active Leaders) Research in Physics; (d) modeling atomic and molecular properties, particularly those occurring under the influence of electric, magnetic, and electromagnetic perturbations; and (e) synthesis of of thiophene-based room temperature ionic liquids and the testing of such ionic liquids as media for organic synthesis.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal for this project was to strengthen undergraduate education and research at Southeastern Louisiana University through the upgrade of our research infrastructure. Toward this goal, the acquisition of a 400 MHz FTNMR instrument was of paramount importance as many courses taught at the Department of Chemistry and Physics here at Southeastern Louisiana University, as well as our nationally-competitive undergraduate research program rely primarily on this piece of equipment. In fact, the acquisition of this instrument that replaced the 20+-year-old failing 300 MHz NMR we used to have in the Department has rejuvenated our American Chemical Society certified chemistry program. The new NMR has been incorporated in the Organic Chemistry laboratory, the Physical Chemistry laboratory, the Instrumental course, and in a special topics class on NMR spectroscopy.  

In the Organic Chemistry laboratory, students are asked to elucidate the structure of an unknown compound based on classical wet chemistry tests.  They then run the NMR on their individual unknown compound with the assistance of the instructor, and compare the NMR results with the results from their classical tests.  This exercise gives them the opportunity to see firsthand the value of NMR spectroscopy in elucidating and validating the structure of compounds.  It also is the first opportunity many of these students have to work independently on a problem and to use modern techniques in helping to solve a problem.  In addition, the NMR is used to help characterize several of the products from the synthesis labs in Organic Chemistry.

In the Physical Chemistry laboratory, students participated in one lab where they made equilibrium measurements on tautomeric systems. In another lab, they looked at rates of reaction at different temperatures to derive the activation energy for the reaction.  They also have used the instrument to examine the acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of pyruvic acid.  In this lab they determined rate constants for the forward and reverse reactions.  With the temperature control on the instrument, they made an Arrhenius plot to determine the reaction's activation energy.

In the Instrumental Class, the students learn about the operation of the instrument, and work on solving the structure of an assigned unknown, while in the special topics NMR spectroscopy class, they learned about the theory of NMR, the interpretation of 1D, multinuclear, and 2D NMR. They are also introduced to the practical aspects of running the instrument.  Each student is given an unknown compound, and they are asked to run 1HNMR, 13CNMR, DEPT, COSY, HMBC and HSQC.  They are then instructed to identify the unknown based on their spectroscopic findings, to fully explain their spectra, and to write up their findings as per requirements for an organic chemistry journal.  

On the research front, this piece of equipment has given a new life to our undergraduate research program, with several undergraduate students using the NMR instrument in their daily experiments as a primary characterization tool. This instrument has also opened the door to new collaborative research programs between the faculty members from our department and their peers from other institutions. The PI (Dr. Dolliver) maintains an active collaboration with Drs. Kevin Shaughnessy and Tim Snowden at the University of Alabama on a project involving the synthesis of single geometric isomers of oxime ethers and the asymmetric reduction of these single isomers, while the Co-PI (Dr. Fotie) has recently started a collaborative project with Dr. Augustin E. Nkengfack, Professor and Head of the Department of Organic Chemistry at the University of Yaoundé I, Cameroon. The project aims to investigate natural products from Cameroonian medicinal plants as potential drugs candidates against a wide range of human diseases.

In summary, the acquisition of this new 400 MHz NMR has in many ways improved the quality of education provided at the Department of Chemistry and Physics at Southeastern Louisiana University by strengthening our curriculum and enhancing our undergraduate research program. It has also enabled faculty members from the department to provide students with a hands-on experience crucial to learning what chemical research is all about.  This allows them to make informed decisions for their future careers. This additional training makes them better candidates for professional and graduate schools or job placement after graduation.
